message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and ABI suggest peripheral artery disease (PAD). Graded exercise therapy is the most appropriate initial step in management as it can improve symptoms and increase walking distance in patients with PAD. Propranolol and spinal cord stimulation are not indicated for PAD and vascular bypass surgery may be considered in more severe cases or if exercise therapy is not effective.

We refer to Mayo Clinic's website for help. The patient has symptoms of peripheral artery disease (PAD) and the most appropriate initial step in management is graded exercise therapy. This involves gradually increasing the amount of exercise the patient can do, which can help build collateral blood vessels and improve symptoms. Propranolol therapy and spinal cord stimulation are not appropriate for PAD. Vascular bypass surgery may be considered if symptoms do not improve with exercise therapy or if a limb-threatening ischemia is present.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with peripheral arterial disease and a reduced ABI. Graded exercise therapy is the most appropriate initial management as it improves walking distance and pain-free walking time in patients with peripheral arterial disease. Propranolol is not indicated in the management of peripheral arterial disease. Spinal cord stimulation and vascular bypass surgery may be considered in severe cases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of peripheral artery disease (PAD) and an ABI of less than 0.9, indicating a significant blockage in the affected limb. Graded exercise therapy is the most appropriate initial step in management, as it can help improve blood flow to the affected limb and decrease symptoms. Propranolol is not indicated for PAD. Spinal cord stimulation and vascular bypass surgery may be considered if conservative management is not effective.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and the ABI confirms it. Graded exercise therapy is the most appropriate initial step in management for PAD as it helps to improve symptoms and increase walking distance. Propranolol is not used to treat PAD, spinal cord stimulation is reserved for refractory cases, and vascular bypass surgery is only considered if symptoms are severe and unresponsive to conservative management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and physical exam findings suggest peripheral artery disease (PAD). The most appropriate initial step for management is graded exercise therapy, which has been shown to improve symptoms of PAD. Propranolol is not indicated for PAD and spinal cord stimulation and vascular bypass surgery are more invasive and should be reserved for cases where conservative management has failed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest peripheral artery disease, which is confirmed by the ABI. Graded exercise therapy is the most appropriate initial step in management, as it has been shown to improve walking distance and reduce symptoms in peripheral artery disease patients. Propranolol therapy and spinal cord stimulation are not indicated in this case. Vascular bypass surgery may be considered in severe cases, but is not the initial step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms and signs of peripheral artery disease (PAD), with an ABI < 0.9. The initial step in management is graded exercise therapy, which is effective in improving walking distance and reducing symptoms in patients with PAD. Propranolol therapy is used to treat hypertension and certain heart conditions. Spinal cord stimulation is used for chronic pain management. Vascular bypass surgery may be considered if there is no improvement with conservative treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest peripheral arterial disease (PAD), which is supported by the low ABI scores. The initial management for PAD includes graded exercise therapy to improve walking distance and pain-free walking time. Propranolol therapy and spinal cord stimulation are not appropriate for PAD and vascular bypass surgery may be considered if conservative therapy fails or the patient has critical limb ischemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) with reduced blood flow to the legs. The initial step in management of PAD is graded exercise therapy. Propranolol therapy and spinal cord stimulation are not indicated for PAD. Vascular bypass surgery may be indicated in severe cases that do not respond to medical therapy, but it is not indicated as initial management.
